description.narrative: AIPP'mål är att arbeta för ursprungsbefolkningen i Asien och ge dem möjlighet att effektivt delta i demokratiska och politiska processer genom att främja och skydda deras rättigheter. Samt att ge dem tillgång till alla former av media utan att diskrimineras.

Asia Indigenous Peoples Pact´s overall objective is that indigenous people in Asia are effectively participating in democratic and political processes through the promotion and protection of their rights to have access to all forms of media withouth discrimination.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: While the actual reporting on the specific indicators is forthcoming (AIPP will complement), the following accomplishments are noted: Networking: Indigenous Voices in Asia Network (IVAN) has been expanded to include 110 members at the global, regional and national levels. AIPP states that this expansion has increased its engagement with a variety of organizations and that national level networks have been strengthened. Capacity building: Several capacity building activities have been conducted ranging from writing for local and national print media to radio and TV broadcasting including use of social media. A total of 149 indigenous individuals have gained media knowledge and skills. As a result, AIPP states, that indigenous media reporters are effectively reporting at various media channels as well as supportive networks of media representatives who continue to report on the issues of indigenous peoples. This has likewise, according to AIPP, contributed to modifications in policies and practices that are now more favourable to the indigenous peoples. Awareness raising: Efforts in this area are being sustained through different channels that include websites, online, print and social media, audio/visual materials, radio programs,books and other educational materials. There is, according to AIPP, a significant increase in the awareness of the general public regarding issues that pertain to indigenous peoples through the AIPP website (number of hits has significantly increased). Other materials have also increased public awareness about and knowledge of the progress of indigenous peoples’ movements as well as culture and practices. The evaluation of the Sida support to AIPP – finalized in February 2015 – accounts for the results attained by the end of 2014 (prior to the current reporting period but to serve as an important complement). These results have emanated from the capacity building efforts that reached more than 500 indigenous individuals in media skills covering topics such as writing for print media and radio broadcasting. The capacity building events were conducted in partnership with indigenous organizations in Cambodia, Indonesia, Nepal, Philippines, and Thailand. Key accomplishments: -Improved capacity of indigenous journalists and activists to report on the adverse conditions faced by their communities and the publishing of these accounts in the national media. -Strengthened development of indigenous media, specifically community radio, in addition to the establishment of networks of indigenous activists and media representatives across Asia. -Fostered supportive networks of indigenous citizen journalists and activists and media representatives, who continue to report on issues of concern to indigenous peoples. -Amplified the amount and frequency of media reporting on indigenous issues, which has been seen to contribute towards modifications in the development of policies and professional practices that are more favourable to indigenous peoples.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
